column2: officially the City of Poughkeepsie
column3: separate from the Town of Poughkeepsie) is a city in the U.S. state of New York. It is the county seat of Dutchess County with a 2019 census-estimated population of 30
column4: 515. Poughkeepsie is in the Hudson River Valley region
column5: midway between the core of the New York metropolitan area and the state capital of Albany. It is a principal city of the Poughkeepsie–Newburgh–Middletown metropolitan area which belongs to the New York metropolitan area. It is served by the nearby Hudson Valley Regional Airport and Stewart International Airport in Orange County
column6: New York.

column1: Poughkeepsie has been called "The Queen City of the Hudson". It was settled in the 17th century by the Dutch and became New York State's second capital shortly after the American Revolution. It was chartered as a city in 1854. Major bridges in the city include the Walkway over the Hudson
column2: a former railroad bridge called the Poughkeepsie Bridge which re-opened as a public walkway on October 3
column4: and the Mid-Hudson Bridge
column5: a major thoroughfare built in 1930 that carries U.S. Route 44 over the Hudson. The city of Poughkeepsie lies in New York's 18th congressional district.Poughkeepsie is situated between the Lower Hudson and the Capital District regions
column6: and the city's economy is stimulated by several major corporations
column7: including IBM. Educational institutions include Marist College
column9: Dutchess Community College and The Culinary Institute of America.

column1: The name Poughkeepsie is derived from a word in the Wappinger language
column2: roughly U-puku-ipi-sing
column3: meaning "the reed-covered lodge by the little-water place"
column4: referring to a spring or stream feeding into the Hudson River south of the downtown area.

column1: English colonist Robert Sanders and Dutch colonist Myndert Harmense Van Den Bogaerdt acquired the land from a local Native American tribe in 1686
column2: and the first settlers were the families of Barent Baltus Van Kleeck and Hendrick Jans van Oosterom. The settlement grew quickly
column3: and the Reformed Church of Poughkeepsie was established by 1720.

column1: The community was set off from the town of Poughkeepsie when it became an incorporated village on March 27
column2: 1799. The city of Poughkeepsie was chartered on March 28
column3: 1854. The city and town of Poughkeepsie are generally viewed as a single place and are commonly referred to collectively as "Poughkeepsie"
column4: with a combined population of 74
column5: 751 in 2018.The city of Poughkeepsie was spared from battle during the American Revolutionary War and became the second capital of New York State. In 1788
column6: the Ratification Convention for New York State included Alexander Hamilton
column8: and George Clinton. They assembled at the courthouse on Market Street and ratified the United States Constitution
column9: and New York State entered the new union as the eleventh of the original Thirteen Colonies to become the United States. In 1799
column10: a new seal was created for the city.

column1: Poughkeepsie was a major center for whale rendering
column2: and the industry flourished during the 19th century through shipping
column3: millineries
column4: paper mills
column5: and several breweries along the Hudson River
column6: including some owned by Matthew Vassar
column7: founder of Vassar College. Families built palatial weekend homes nearby
column11: due to the area's natural beauty and proximity to New York City. The Vanderbilt Mansion is located several miles up the Hudson from Poughkeepsie in the town of Hyde Park and is registered as a national historic site; it is considered to be a sterling example of the mansions built by American industrialists during the late 19th century. The city is home to the Bardavon 1869 Opera House
column12: the oldest continuously operating entertainment venue in the state.

column1: The city of Poughkeepsie is located on the western edge of Dutchess County
column2: in Downstate New York's Hudson River Valley Area.

column1: It is bordered by the town of Lloyd across the Hudson River to the west and by the town of Poughkeepsie on the north
column2: east and south. There are two crossings of the Hudson River in Poughkeepsie: the Mid-Hudson Bridge for motor vehicles and pedestrians
column3: and the pedestrian Walkway over the Hudson.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has an area of 5.7 square miles (14.8 km2)
column3: of which 5.1 square miles (13.3 km2) is land
column4: and 0.23 square miles (0.6 km2) (10.05%) is water. Poughkeepsie lies approximately 75 miles (121 km) north of the center of the New York megacity. It is 73.5 miles (118.28 km) south of the New York state capital of Albany. The highest elevation of Poughkeepsie is 380 feet above sea level on College Hill. Its lowest is on the Hudson River.

column1: Poughkeepsie makes up a part of the Poughkeepsie—Newburgh—Middletown metropolitan statistical area
column2: which is a part of the wider NY-NJ-CT combined statistical area.

Poughkeepsie has a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa) with relatively hot summers and cold winters. It receives approximately 44.12 inches (1
column2: 121 mm) of precipitation per year
column3: much of which is delivered in the late spring and early summer. Due to its inland location
column4: Poughkeepsie can be very cold during the winter
column5: with temperatures dropping below zero a few times per year. Poughkeepsie can also be hit by powerful nor'easters
column6: but it usually receives significantly less snow or rain from these storms compared to locations towards the south and east.

nearly 54% of Poughkeepsie and its surrounding area have religious affiliation. The largest Christian organization is the Catholic Church (37.8%)
column3: served by the Latin Church-based Archdiocese of New York. The second and third largest Christian organizations are Methodism (2.6%) and Presbyterianism (2.0%)
column4: which stem from Anglican or Episcopalianism (1.7%). Anglicans or Episcopalians within the city limits and surrounding area are primarily served by the Episcopal Diocese of New York. The fifth largest Christian group is Pentecostalism (1.3%)
column5: followed by Lutheranism (1.1%)
column6: the Baptist Church (0.9%)
column8: and Christians of other denominations including the Eastern Orthodox and United Church of Christ (2.7%). The second largest religious group outside of Christianity is Islam (2.4%). The Islamic community primarily identifies with Sunni Islam in the area.  Following Islam
column9: 0.8% of the population profess Judaism and 0.1% practice an eastern religion.

column1: IBM has a large campus in the adjacent town of Poughkeepsie. It was once referred to as IBM's "Main Plant"
column2: although much of the workforce has been moved elsewhere in the company (2008). The site once built the IBM 700/7000 series of computers as well as the IBM 7030 Stretch computer and later
column3: together with the Endicott site
column4: IBM mainframes. The RS/6000 SP2 family of computers
column5: which came to fame after one of them won a chess match against world chess master Garry Kasparov
column6: were also manufactured by IBM Poughkeepsie. In October 2008
column7: IBM's Poughkeepsie facility was named "Assembly Plant of the Year 2008" by the editors of Assembly Magazine. Poughkeepsie remains IBM's primary design and manufacturing center for its newest mainframes and high-end Power Systems servers
column8: and it is also one of IBM's major software development centers for z/OS and for other products.

column2: Poughkeepsie was home to the Smith Brothers cough drop factory. The Smith Brothers' grave site is in the Poughkeepsie Rural Cemetery.

column1: Poughkeepsie and Dutchess County are within the media market of the New York—New Jersey—Connecticut combined statistical area
column2: though the city is headquarters for The Poughkeepsie Journal
column3: the third-oldest active newspaper in the United States. Poughkeepsie Journal is owned by USA Today. News 12 Hudson Valley is a regional television channel targeting the Poughkeepsie and the Hudson Valley region.

The Poughkeepsie City School District is the public K-12 school system serving approximately 5
column2: 000 students.

column1: The Oakwood Friends School is a co-ed 6–12 boarding school outside the city limits
column2: serving approximately 145 students. It is the oldest college preparatory school in New York State. Poughkeepsie Day School
column3: also outside the city
column4: is a progressive co-ed pre-K-through-12 day school serving 300 students founded in 1934 by local families and members of the Vassar College faculty. Other private schools in the area include Tabernacle Christian Academy.

column1: Two institutions of higher learning operate campuses within the city: Adelphi University's Hudson Valley Center and the Ridley-Lowell Business and Technical Institute.The Culinary Institute of America's main campus is located in the suburb of Hyde Park
column2: north of the city of Poughkeepsie. Dutchess Community College
column3: Marist College
column4: and Vassar College are all located in the surrounding Town of Poughkeepsie.

column1: The city is protected by the career firefighters in the City of Poughkeepsie Fire Department. By keeping buildings up to code
column2: controlling illegal occupancies
column3: monitoring the safety of living areas and issuing licenses and permits
column4: the department works to limit the potential for dangerous situations and the occurrences of fire hazards. The Poughkeepsie Fire Department operates out of three fire stations
column5: located throughout the city
column6: and operates and maintains a fire apparatus fleet of four engines
column7: including one reserve engine; two ladder trucks; one rescue vehicle
column8: cross-staffed as needed; and one fireboat. The Arlington Fire District
column10: and New Hamburg Fire Department cover the surrounding town of Poughkeepsie. The Fire Department is capable of handling fires
column12: extractions and natural disasters. It is a certified Emergency Medical Services first responder fire department and first responder to calls with Mobile Life Support Services.

column1: Police protection to the city is provided by the City of Poughkeepsie Police Department. The police department has over 125 employees
column2: including 96 sworn police officers and 34 civilians
column3: of which 13 are emergency dispatchers. The Police Department also operate a Citizen Observer Alert Network to keep citizens informed about local crime
column4: emergency situations
column5: and other important information. The Dutchess County Sheriff Station is based in Poughkeepsie and is adjacent to the Dutchess County Jail
column6: which houses around 275–300 inmates maximum capacity at any time.

column1: Poughkeepsie is home to Vassar Brothers Medical Center
column2: a 365-bed hospital situated next to U.S. Route 9 on Reade Place. The hospital has an advanced birthing center and a Level III Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. Vassar Brother Medical Center is owned and operated by Nuvance Health (formerly HealthQuest)
column3: a local nonprofit collection of hospitals and healthcare providers.Emergency medical services are provided by Mobile Life Support Services
column4: which are contracted to provide full-time ambulance coverage to the city. They provide paramedic level service
column5: including advanced life support and has ambulances stationed in the city on Pershing Avenue. Mobile Life also has a staff of specially trained paramedics that provide tactical Emergency Medical Services support to the city police during ESU/SWAT operations
column6: as well as emergency responses for the Fire Department via their Special Operations Response Team. They also provide advanced life support ambulance service to other agencies and municipalities in Dutchess
column9: and their headquarters building is located in New Windsor in Orange County.

column1: Poughkeepsie sits at the junction of the north–south US 9 and east–west US 44 and NY 55 highways.

Rail commuter service to New York City is provided at the Poughkeepsie Metro-North station by the MTA's Metro-North Railroad. Poughkeepsie is the northern terminus of Metro-North's Hudson Line. Amtrak also serves the station
column2: along the Hudson River south to New York City's Pennsylvania Station and north along the river to Albany-Rensselaer station and points further north and west. Amtrak trains serving Poughkeepsie are the Adirondack
column3: Empire Service
column4: Ethan Allen Express
column5: Maple Leaf
column6: and Lake Shore Limited.

column2: opened in 1930
column3: carries US 44 and NY 55 across the Hudson River from Poughkeepsie to Highland. The Poughkeepsie Bridge opened in 1888 to carry railroad traffic across the Hudson
column4: but all usage of the bridge came to an end when a 1974 fire damaged its decking. A local group (Walkway over the Hudson) raised the funds to convert the bridge into a unique linear park connecting rail trails on both sides of the Hudson River. The Walkway Over The Hudson opened on October 3
column6: coinciding with the 400th anniversary of Henry Hudson's first exploration of the river named for him. The bridge is now open for pedestrian and bicycle use and is a state historic park.

column1: The Dutchess County Airport in nearby Wappinger services general aviation
column2: although it once had scheduled air carrier service by Colonial Airlines in the 1950s and regional airline service by Command Airways and others in the 1960s–1980s. The nearest major airport to Poughkeepsie is Stewart International Airport about 25 miles (40 km) south in Newburgh. Other nearby airports include Westchester County Airport approximately 58.1 miles (93 km) south
column3: Albany International Airport approximately 85 miles (137 km) north and the three major metropolitan airports for New York City: John F. Kennedy International Airport approximately 88 miles (142 km) south
column4: Newark Liberty International Airport approximately 88 miles (142 km) south
column5: and LaGuardia Airport approximately 80 miles (130 km) south.

column3: which travels throughout Dutchess County and also serves as the main link to the Route 9 corridor including Poughkeepsie Galleria and South Hills Mall.

column1: The Hudson Valley Renegades are a minor league baseball team affiliated with the Tampa Bay Rays. The team is a member of the New York–Penn League
column2: and play at Dutchess Stadium in the nearby town of Fishkill.

column1: The Hudson Valley Hawks were a team in the National Professional Basketball League until 2009 when the league disbanded. The team's home court was at Beacon High School
column2: located approximately 16 miles south in the city of Beacon.

column1: The Hudson Valley Highlanders of the North American Football League played their home games at Dietz Stadium in nearby Kingston.
Poughkeepsie hosted a founding member of the North Eastern Hockey League with the formation of the Poughkeepsie Panthers in 2003. However
column2: due to financial problems
column3: the team only played for one season
column4: and became the Connecticut Cougars the following year. The league folded due financial problems in January 2008. Subsequently
column5: the city was home to the Hudson Valley Bears
column6: one of four founding members of the Eastern Professional Hockey League
column7: for one season. Both teams played their home games at the McCann Ice Arena in the Mid-Hudson Civic Center.

column1: One of Poughkeepsie's most notable sports events was the annual Poughkeepsie Regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association
column2: which was held on the Hudson River from 1895 to 1949. The top college teams would attend along with tens of thousands of spectators. Poughkeepsie was known as the rowing capital of the world. Spectators watched from the hills and bluffs overlooking the river and from chartered boats and trains that followed the races along the entire length of the course; which were longer than present-day races
column3: with varsity eights rowing a 4-mile (6.4 km) race. When the rowing association moved the regatta to other venues
column4: the Mid-Hudson Rowing Association was formed to preserve rowing in the area. It successfully lobbied to preserve the regatta's facilities for use by area high schools and club rowing programs. As part of the 400th anniversary celebration of Henry Hudson's trip up the Hudson River a recreation of the regatta was held with Marist College Crew as its host. The events included a fireworks display
column5: a large dinner
column6: and the unveiling of the restored historic Cornell Boathouse
column7: now property of Marist Crew. Historically accurate
column8: the four mile long course started off Rogers Point in Hyde Park and ended about a mile south of the Poughkeepsie-Highland Railroad Bridge. Competitors included Marist
column14: Columbia and Cornell. Notably this was the first time women's crew teams were allowed to participate in the historic Poughkeepsie Regatta.

column1: Established British racing team Carlin Motorsport have chosen Poughkeepsie as their U.S. base whilst racing in Indy Lights.
